Package com.noctarius.borabora

borabora is a CBOR, the Concise Binary Object Representation, skip-scan processor which consists of a generator as well as a parser.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Dictionary
    A Dictionary is a map of key-value data items.
    Input
    An Input instance represents a source for readable data.
    Output
    An Output instance represents a target sink for writeable data.
    Parser
    The Parser class is the entry point for all parsing related activities.
    Query
    The Query interface represents any kind of prepared statement like query to be executed against any of the Parser data querying or extraction methods.
    Sequence
    A Sequence is a list of value data items.
    Value
    A Value represents a known or unknown data item in borabora.
    ValueType
    A ValueType implementation represent value types to further specification over a MajorType definition.
    Writer
    The Writer interface is used to create new writers to generate the CBOR data streams from Java data structures and values.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    HalfPrecisionFloat
    A HalfPrecisionFloat instance represents a 16 bit floating point type as defined in the IEEE 754 specification, also known as binary16.
    Predicates
    The Predicates class contains parsing optimized utility methods to provide Predicate matchers against Dictionary keys or values or Sequence values.
    ValuePrettyPrinter
    The ValuePrettyPrinter class provides a pretty printer implementation for borabora CBOR Values.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    MajorType
    The MajorType enum defines the basic types as specified by the CBOR specification (RFC 7049).
    ValueTypes
    The ValueTypes class is a set of prebuilt ValueType implementations.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    NoSuchByteException
    The NoSuchByteException signals the state of reaching an unexpected end of the stream or the read destination (in case of a byte-array).
    QueryParserException
    The QueryParseException type is thrown for any kind of parsing exception, while parsing a query language string.
    WrongTypeException
    The WrongTypeException is commonly thrown on occasions where a wrong type is assumed by a query.

Package com.noctarius.borabora Description

borabora is a CBOR, the Concise Binary Object Representation, skip-scan processor which consists of a generator as well as a parser. While parsing all operations are implemented as lazily as possible, whereas writing is immediate.

CBOR itself is a very effective binary protocol, modelled after the basic ideas of JSON, however employs more diverse data types and is extensible to future purpose.

Skip-scan means, that the parser scans the actual data type of an item in the stream, calculates its byte length and skips the bytes if the item if of no interest.

Using borabora, you're not directly working with native types directly but all queries result in a generalized type, called Value, which will be lazily (on user request) deserialized into the actual data type and value. Up to this point nothing is actually read.

The API is kept simple but powerful. Reading CBOR data with borabora consists mainly of creating a Parser instance, wrapping any king of source into an Input implementation, parsing or fluent-building a query and putting all parts together into an actual read request. The following code snippet shows the basic flow of how borabora is used.

     Parser parser = Parser.newBuilder().build();
     Input input = Input.fromByteArray( getByteArray() );
     Query query = parser.newQueryBuilder().build();
     Value value = parser.read(input, query);

The previous example wraps the byte-array returned from the method getByteArry into an Input instance and executes it against the Parser and Query to return the actual result of the query as a Value instance.

Furthermore it is important to note, that Parser and Query instances are stateless and thread-safe which means they can easily be shared between different threads and can be used concurrently. This is true as long as the Input implementation is thread-safe as well and employs the provided offset as a read position. There might be implementations where this assumption does not hold true, for example if backed by a java.net.SocketInputStream, whereas those kind of implementations are not provided out of the box.
